The loss of Senator Winters will not only be felt in Salem, but all across Oregon. Mylene and I send our sincerest condolences and prayers to the Winters family, her friends, and her colleagues during this difficult time.

To say that Senator Jackie Winters was a pioneer in Oregon is an understatement. She was a role model for women, the first African American Republican elected to the legislature, and a true leader for our state.

I knew that when he asked questions, he had done his homeowork, and I had confidence that his reporting would be grounded in the facts. My prayers are with Robert's family and colleagues as they grieve his passing.

With Robert Pear's passing, America has lost one of our finest and fairest journalists. He took time to come to my district in Oregon to learn about rural health care first hand. He frequently covered our work on the Energy and Commerce Committee.

In the 20 town halls I've held across our district so far this year, I can’t think of a time that someone didn’t ask the question, “How can we put a stop to unwanted robocalls?” This is a real problem, and I outline real solutions in the @EastOregonian >> https://www.eastoregonian.com/opinion/columnists/walden-hanging-up-on-robocalls/article_368d6ba0-6de1-11e9-b0ff-6318b67e0b57.html …
Thank you for your service, Don.  https://www.ktvz.com/news/bend-korean-war-veteran-gets-surprise-purple-heart-in-dc/1074586262 …

It was my great honor and privilege to present Don Van Cleve Jr. his Purple Heart yesterday at the Korean War Memorial - a memorial dedicated to those "who answered the call to defend a country they never knew and a people they never met."
Don went many years and never received the Purple Heart he earned for his service to our country. After hearing about his case, my office helped secure the distinguished medal.

That didn’t tell his whole story to his parents. Don's parents would later learn that he was in a fox hole with other Marines when an incoming grenade exploded near his helmet - he lost hearing in one ear and still has shrapnel in his back today.

9/29/1951 - the parents of Don Van Cleve Jr., of Bend, read the following telegram: "We regret to inform you that your son PFC Donald Lewis Van Cleve Jr. USMC has been wounded in action 24 September 1951 in the Korean area in the performance of his duty & service of his country." pic.twitter.com/l9UUv2793W

Ken Austin represented the best of Oregon. Entrepreneur, philanthropist, “Benny Beaver”, he created an amazing company at ADEC, & he gave back so much to his community, to our great state & to the world. A giant has left us, & I will always cherish his kindness & friendship.

Today, I had the honor of welcoming 25 WW2 & Korean War vets from Honor Flight of Central OR to our nation's capital. It was a privilege to talk to each vet & present them with American flags flown over the Capitol in recognition of their service to our great country. pic.twitter.com/uKn2mBuCNb
